channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tear Gas Clears Path for Trump to Visit Church
item.description: Police officers used flash grenades to disperse a crowd so the president could visit for a photo opportunity. And in New York, protesters and looters defied a curfew.
item.media:description: Protesters outside the White House, where President Trump called violent demonstrations in American cities “domestic terrorism.”

item.title: How Minneapolis, One of America’s Most Liberal Cities, Struggles With Racism
item.description: The Midwestern city that has been the site of unrest views itself as embracing multiculturalism. But it also struggles with segregation and racial gaps on education.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers helped clear water on Saturday after a Wells Fargo bank was destroyed the night before during protests in Minneapolis.

item.title: As Coronavirus Toll Preoccupies U.S., Rivals Test Limits of American Power
item.description: The coronavirus may have changed almost everything, but it didn’t change this: Global competition spins ahead — and in many ways has accelerated.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Australia Department Of Defence, via Reuters
item.media:description: The amphibious assault ship America conducted maneuvers with other Australian and U.S. Navy vessels in the South China Sea in April, one of four such operations this year.

item.title: Is America’s Pandemic Waning or Raging? Yes
item.description: A single day reveals divergent realities across the country: As cases drop in the Northeast and some cities reopen, other places report stubbornly high numbers.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Lyndon French for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chicago has been shuttered since March, with little hope that life in America’s third-largest city will return to normal soon.

item.title: E.R. Visits Drop Sharply During Pandemic
item.description: People even with heart problems are avoiding emergency rooms because they are worried about possible coronavirus infection, according to a C.D.C. report.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Misha Friedman for The New York Times
item.media:description: NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. While hospitals in virus hot spots were often overwhelmed by the numbers of seriously ill Covid-19 patients, there were drastic declines in the volume of visits to emergency rooms across the country.

item.title: Trump Campaign Looks at Electoral Map and Doesn’t Like What It Sees
item.description: As polls show President Trump significantly trailing his rival, Joseph R. Biden Jr., his campaign is spending heavily in states, like Ohio, that it had hoped would not be competitive at all this year.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: President Trump is trailing his Democratic rival, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., in every public poll of the election, but he has a large war chest and a solid political foundation on the right.

item.title: Drew Brees Criticized for Calling Kneeling During the Anthem ‘Disrespectful’
item.description: Some of those who criticized Brees’s remarks were prominent professional sports figures, including members of his own team.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: New Orleans Saints quarterback Drew Brees after an NFL football game against the Carolina Panthers last season.

item.title: Genes May Leave Some People More Vulnerable to Severe Covid-19
item.description: Geneticists have turned up intriguing links between DNA and the disease. Patients with Type A blood, for example, seem to be at greater risk.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: A transmission electron microscope image of a U.S. case of coronavirus.

item.title: With Steve King Gone, Does the Democrat Have a Shot in His Iowa District?
item.description: J.D. Scholten was preparing for a rematch with Mr. King, the controversial Iowa congressman. Then Mr. King lost the Republican primary.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:description: J.D. Scholten was only about 10,000 votes shy of defeating Representative Steve King in 2018.

item.title: Virginia Governor Plans to Order Robert E. Lee Statue Removed
item.description: A statue of the Confederate general in Richmond is controlled by the state, but the city’s mayor said he would propose a bill to remove additional Confederate monuments there.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:description: Protesters of the death of George Floyd chanted “Tear it down” on Tuesday as they gathered around a statue of Robert E. Lee, a Confederate general, in Richmond, Va.

item.title: Historic Wins for Women of Color as Nation Protests Systemic Racism
item.description: Amid widespread protests against police brutality and the coronavirus pandemic, a determined electorate pushed turnout past 2016 levels.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein, Jennifer Medina and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: Mayor-elect Ella Jones in Ferguson, Mo., on Wednesday. She will become the first black person and first woman to lead the city.

item.title: Gulf of Mexico ‘Dead Zone’ Will Be Large This Summer, Scientists Predict
item.description: The low-oxygen zone can cause harm not just to marine life, but also to those who catch shrimp and fish for their livelihood.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.media:description: Algal blooms in 2007 where the Mississippi flows into the Gulf of Mexico.

item.title: After a Week of Turmoil, a Community Rallies
item.description: As protests over George Floyd’s death continue, many in Minneapolis have joined together to clean, heal and organize more demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Elijah Walker, Pierre-Antoine Louis and Caroline Yang
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times

item.title: Tonys Benefit Event Postponed Amid Unrest
item.description: Broadway.com delayed its “Show of Shows,” set to air Sunday online, in solidarity with those “in the fight for equality and unity” after George Floyd’s death, the site said.
item.dc:creator: Peter Libbey
item.category: Show of Shows: Broadway.com Salutes the Tonys (Play)
item.media:description: Broadway.com had planned a theater celebration to help make up for the lack of the Tonys on Sunday.

item.title: Obama Voices Support for George Floyd Protesters and Calls for Police Reform
item.description: Mr. Obama, offering a starkly more upbeat assessment of peaceful protesters and their motives than President Trump has, urged people to “remember that this country was founded on protest — it is called the American Revolution.”
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush

item.title: Man Shelters Over 70 Protesters Fleeing Arrest in His Washington Home
item.description: Rahul Dubey said he welcomed a “tsunami” of people, some of whom had been pepper-sprayed, into his home on Monday night: “The first hour and half that everyone was in here was pure mayhem.”
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Demonstrators protested in front of the White House on Monday.

item.title: New Study Finds Hydroxychloroquine Did Not Prevent Covid-19
item.description: The first carefully controlled trial of hydroxychloroquine given to people exposed to the coronavirus did not show any benefit.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.media:description: Boxes of hydroxychloroquine in a hospital pharmacy in Porto Alegre, Brazil. The Trump administration said Sunday it had sent 2 million doses of the drug to Brazil.

item.title: Former U.A.W. President Gary Jones Pleads Guilty
item.description: Mr. Jones, who was accused of embezzling $1 million, will cooperate with federal prosecutors who have been investigating corruption at the autoworkers union.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: Gary Jones, the former president of the United Auto Workers union, acknowledged using more than $1 million in union funds for himself.

item.title: Contact Tracing Could Be Much Easier — but There Are Tradeoffs
item.description: Lots of new app ideas are emerging to track Covid-19, but each has issues around privacy, location accuracy and how much appeal it will have to the public and to health officials.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.media:description: A French police officer checked the QR code of a driver in Paris during the nationwide lockdown last month. Technologies like Bluetooth and QR codes could help officials contact-trace, but challenges of privacy and access abound.

item.title: Confederate Statue Debate Is Reignited by George Floyd Protests
item.description: Dozens came down after a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville, Va., in 2017. Protesters outraged over the death of Mr. Floyd are targeting some that remained.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz and Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Ryan M. Kelly/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Robert E. Lee statue at the center of the 2017 protests in Charlottesville, Va., still stands, surrounded by a small plastic construction fence and “No Trespassing” signs.

item.title: Pope Francis Calls Unrest in U.S. ‘Disturbing’
item.description: The pope was the latest leader to speak out about social unrest in the United States after the death of George Floyd. Former Presidents Jimmy Carter, George W. Bush and Barack Obama have also commented.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Vatican Media, via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Pope Francis, center, at his weekly general audience in Vatican City on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump and Aides Try to Change the Narrative of the White House Protests
item.description: Their accounts have been contradicted by eyewitnesses.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Trump returning to the White House after walking to St. John’s Episcopal Church on Monday.

item.title: Snapchat Stopped Promoting Trump Account
item.description: The social media company’s decision follows Twitter’s moves to label Mr. Trump’s posts inaccurate or as inciting violence.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang and Kate Conger
item.media:description: Snap said it planned to stop promoting the Snapchat account of President Trump on its Discover feature.

item.title: Could There Be a More Difficult Time to Become an Arts Leader?
item.description: As many cultural institutions are dealing with layoffs and furloughs, some are appointing new leaders who face a whole new set of challenges.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.category: Museum of Contemporary Art in Toronto
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Children’s Museum of Manhattan is one of a score of museums naming new directors. It hopes to win approval for a new home and rethink exhibitions for the coronavirus era.

item.title: Trump Administration to Block Chinese Airlines From Flying to the U.S.
item.description: The decision comes after Chinese regulators effectively prevented American airlines from resuming service to their country at a moment of rising tension.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Ana Swanson
item.media:description: China Eastern Airlines is among the major Chinese carriers that operates direct flights between the United States and China.

item.title: Statue of Frank Rizzo, Former Philadelphia Mayor, Is Removed After Protests
item.description: Demonstrators had tried to topple the statue of the former mayor and police commissioner, who once urged voters to “vote white.”
item.dc:creator: Jon Hurdle and Maria Cramer
item.media:description: A vandalized statue of the former Mayor Frank Rizzo of Philadelphia, who also served as the city’s police commissioner, was guarded by State Police over the weekend.

item.title: Senate Approves More Time to Spend Paycheck Protection Loans: Live Business Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Protests in L.A.: What's Changed Since Rodney King
item.description: Wednesday: Although the parallels with the Rodney King riots are clear, a lot has changed.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters blocked the intersection of Figueroa and Olympic in downtown Los Angeles on Friday.

item.title: Fact Checking Trump's False Claims on Twitter
item.description: We analyzed the president’s Twitter feed for a week. A third of his posts contained falsehoods or murky accusations, underscoring the challenge to Twitter’s chief, Jack Dorsey, of policing him.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House on Monday.

item.title: Pandemic Could Scar a Generation of Working Mothers
item.description: Working from home has highlighted and compounded the heavier domestic burden borne by women. Now office reopenings may force new career sacrifices.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Tiffany Hsu
item.media:credit: Da'Shaunae Marisa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Virgina Dressler spends her days at home caring for her 3-year-old twins while managing a career as a digital librarian.

item.title: Steve King Sinks in Iowa
item.description: Protesters went back to the streets and, oh, elections took place: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: When Jail Becomes Normal
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: The exercise yard at California Medical Facility in Vacaville, Calif.

item.title: Live Coronavirus Updates
item.description: The Trump administration chose five companies as the most likely to produce a vaccine. The tally of new cases is rising in the U.S., partly because of expanded testing. Italy ends travel restrictions.
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn in April.

item.title: 3 Other Officers Charged; Chauvin Murder Charge Upgraded: Live Updates
item.description: As unrest over race and policing roils the nation, Virginia’s governor pledges to remove a much-contested statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee.
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Thompson, a candidate for the Minnesota House, addressed protesters at a memorial for George Floyd in Minneapolis on Wednesday.

item.title: The Journalism Students Helping The Times Cover California
item.description: A collaboration between the National desk and the University of California-Berkeley offered a chance at “public service work during this unparalleled time.”
item.dc:creator: John Otis
item.media:description: Katey Rusch reported on shelter-in-place enforcement in Santa Clara County.

item.title: Protests in L.A.: The Ghosts of Rodney King and Watts Rise Again
item.description: Los Angeles has been one of America’s reference points for racial unrest. This time protesters are bringing their anger to the people they say need to hear it most: the white and wealthy.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abandoned police cruiser burned after being set on fire during protests on Beverly Boulevard in west Los Angeles, on Saturday.

item.title: Rod Rosenstein, Key Figure in Russia Inquiry, Defends Mueller Appointment
item.description: But the former deputy attorney general said he would not have signed an application to renew a wiretap on a former Trump adviser if he had known of its flaws.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Katie Benner and Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Rod J. Rosenstein, the former deputy attorney general, arriving Wednesday in the Capitol.

item.title: A World War II Flag Taken During a Reno Protest Is Returned
item.description: The U.S.S. Reno flag was anonymously returned with a note that said it “needed protecting.”
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: A flag from a World War II battleship was anonymously returned to a reporter in Reno, Nev., on Tuesday.

item.title: 5 Takeaways on the C.D.C.’s Coronavirus Response
item.description: Early mistakes in testing, aging data systems, clashes with President Trump and an overly cautious culture shook confidence in the nation’s premier public health agency.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ward for Covid-19 patients on ventilators at University Hospital of Brooklyn.

item.title: The C.D.C. Waited ‘Its Entire Existence for This Moment.’ What Went Wrong?
item.description: The technology was old, the data poor, the bureaucracy slow, the guidance confusing, the administration not in agreement. The coronavirus shook the world’s premier health agency, creating a loss of confidence and hampering the U.S. response to the crisis.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton, Abby Goodnough, Michael D. Shear, Megan Twohey, Apoorva Mandavilli, Sheri Fink and Mark Walker
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Coronavirus patients on ventilators at Elmhurst Hospital in Queens, N.Y., last month.

item.title: Tear Gas Used in George Floyd Protests Could Lead to New Coronavirus Wave
item.description: Tear gas brings temporary misery by stinging eyes and throats. There’s also evidence that it may increase the risk of respiratory illness.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tear gas was deployed on protesters on Sunday, in Ferguson, Mo. “I’m really concerned that this might catalyze a new wave of Covid-19,” a researcher who has studied tear gas said of its use at protests during the pandemic.

item.title: Teresa Leger Fernandez Beats Valerie Plame in New Mexico House Primary
item.description: Ms. Leger Fernandez, a progressive who emphasized her long history in the district, overcame a well-funded challenge from Ms. Plame and defeated several other Democratic rivals.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Ramsay de Give for The New York Times
item.media:description: Teresa Leger Fernandez in Taos Pueblo, N.M., after meeting with Pueblo leaders in January. She received endorsements from high-profile Democrats including Senator Elizabeth Warren and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.

item.title: Ella Jones Is Elected First Black Mayor of Ferguson
item.description: Ms. Jones is also the first woman to lead the Missouri city, which erupted in protests in 2014 after a white police officer shot and killed Michael Brown, a black teenager.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: David Carson/St. Louis Post-Dispatch, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ella Jones, a Ferguson, Mo., city councilwoman, in 2017. She was elected mayor on Tuesday night.

item.title: Steve King, House Republican With a History of Racist Remarks, Loses Primary
item.description: Mr. King, one of the nation’s most divisive elected officials, saw his power in Congress curtailed last year after he questioned why white supremacy was considered offensive.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Steve King of Iowa has long made racist remarks about immigrants, and Republicans had worried before the primary election on Tuesday that he was an electoral liability.

item.title: How Trump’s Idea for a Photo Op Led to Havoc in a Park
item.description: When the history of the Trump presidency is written, the clash with protesters that preceded President Trump’s walk across Lafayette Square may be remembered as one of its defining moments.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker, Maggie Haberman, Katie Rogers, Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Katie Benner, Haley Willis, Christiaan Triebert and David Botti
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Police advance on protesters outside the White House to clear a path for President Trump to walk to St. Johns church in Washington on Monday

item.title: For Police Officers, Demonstrations Take a Toll and Test Duty
item.description: As the world watches demonstrations unfold on television and social media, both the best and the worst of American law enforcement has been on display.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez
item.media:credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fireworks thrown by protesters erupt behind officers outside the Police Department in Ferguson, Mo., on Sunday.
